description: Numbers n such that the decimal digits of n^2 can be partitioned into two or more squares.
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 12 is present because 12^2=144 can be partitioned into three squares 1, 4 and 4.108^2 = 11664 = 1_16_64, 120^2 = 14400 = 1_4_400, so 108 and 120 are in the sequence.
prog: (Haskell)a048653 n = a048653_list !! (n-1)a048653_list = filter (f . show . (^ 2)) [1..] where   f zs = g (init $ tail $ inits zs) (tail $ init $ tails zs)   g (xs:xss) (ys:yss)     | h xs      = h ys || f ys || g xss yss     | otherwise = g xss yss     where h ds = head ds /= '0' && a010052 (read ds) == 1   g _ _ = False-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 11 2011
author: _Felice Russo_
extensions: Corrected and extended by _Naohiro Nomoto_, Sep 01 2001
